newsitem.title: USA: CFTC files complaint against New York Forex firm.
newsitem.headline: CFTC files complaint against New York Forex firm.

text.p: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission charged New York Forex Ex-Center Corp with seven counts of violating the Commodity Exchange Act, including illegally offering and selling off-exchange futures contracts.

In an administrative complaint filed Tuesday, the CFTC also charged New York Forex and its president, Peter Lai, with fraudulently soliciting customers, embezzling customer funds and "bucketing" their orders from June 1993 to May 1995.

In addition, the complaint said the firm was not registered as a futures commission merchant, a designation that would allow it to hold customers' money. The firm was registered as a commodity trading adviser from May 20, 1994 to August 2, 1995.
The National Futures Association terminated New York Forex's registration in August 1995, because Lai, the sole principal, had been missing since May 16, 1995.

One month later, New York Forex filed a voluntary petition for bankruptcy in the Southern District of New York, according to the CFTC's complaint. The complaint also said Lai's last known address was in San Jose, California.

Andrew Scudiero, who was also named in the CFTC's seven-count complaint, was never registered as a salesperson but began soliciting customers for New York Forex in the spring of 1995, the complaint said.
The CFTC said Scudiero "appears to be unfit" for registration due to past securities fraud violations and a 1986 narcotics conviction.
CFTC officials could not immediately be reached for comment. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750;E-mail derivatives@reuters.com))
